result.execSummary:
The defendant Cheyenne Robert Hakes was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possession of THC (2nd+ Offense) [Modifiers: Repeater], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Costs + DNA surcharge = $518 - taken from bond on deposit with balance to be returned to bond poster.
DNA sample due by 4:00 pm on 10-6-2022.  AODA and follow through.  Obtain and maintain full time employment.  Completion of all assessments, counseling and follow through as recommended by agent.
Not allowed to vote or serve on a jury until civil rights are restored.   No possession or consumption of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Court reviews case.

Copy of PSI.
ADA heard - no corrections to PSI.
Atty Reabe heard on corrections to PSI.
ADA heard on sentencing recommendation.
Atty Reabe heard on sentencing.
Deft heard.
Court heard on factors.
Court imposed an stayed on Count 1: 
2 years initial confinement, 2 years extended supervision, and places Deft on probation for 2 years.
Eligible for CIP and SAP.
Conditions of probation:
20 days conditional jail, without good time, but with huber release if in compliance with jail rules and regulations.
Credit for 25 days time served.
Payment of costs + fees + DNA surcharge = $518.00 - payment to be taken from bond on deposit with remaining balance to be returned to bond poster.
No possession or consumption of alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription.
AODA and follow through.
Obtain and maintain full time employment.
Completion of all assessments, counseling and follow through as recommended by agent.
No firearms.
May not vote or serve on jury until civil rights are restored.

Appeal rights.
